**The Water and Cloud Collection**

*Scripture Title:* *The Water and Cloud Collection*. Composed by Tan Chuduan of the Jin dynasty. Three juan in length. Source text from the *Zhengtong Daoist Canon*, Taiping Section.

**Preface to The Water and Cloud Collection**

Dongmou was an ancient state of the Muzi, a major commandery of Qi. Its households were vast, and its people simple and unadorned. To the east, it bordered the Bohai Sea, where misty waves and surging clouds stretched boundless, extending for tens of thousands of *li*. To the south, it faced the Kun and Jian mountains, their layered peaks towering into the heavens, rising for thousands of *zhang*. With such a convergence of sea and mountain brilliance, the land was blessed with exceptional talent, and eminent figures and scholars emerged in every generation. It was only fitting that perfected beings and immortals would arise in succession.

Master Tan, styled Chuduan and known as Master Ever-True, hailed from a prominent family of our homeland. From birth, he was keenly perceptive, possessing an extraordinary bearing. Skilled in cursive and clerical script, he was upright and principled, earning the respect and awe of his village. In the *dinghai* year of the Dading era, the Perfected One of Wondrous Conduct and Compassionate Transformation, Chongyang, arrived in the east, his pilgrim’s staff alighting upon the shores. Drawn by past karmic affinities, he sought out old friends. In our homeland, he encountered Master Danyang (Ma), Master Ever-True (Tan), in Donglai Yishui, Master Ever-Living (Liu), and in Dengzhou Qixia, Master Ever-Spring (Qiu). They became a spiritual family beyond the world, known as the Four Masters: Tan, Ma, Qiu, and Liu. Together, they followed the Perfected One’s travels, journeying west to Yimen. There, the Perfected One entrusted them with oral instructions, charged them with future affairs, and then departed this world to ascend as an immortal. After the four completed the burial rites, they led their disciples west to Zhongnan Mountain, the former retreat of the Perfected One. There, they transmitted and inherited his Dao for over a decade. Thereafter, each went their separate ways.

Master Ever-True wandered along the Luo River, transforming and delivering people through his teachings. Wherever he went, followers gathered like clouds. His compositions—odes, rhapsodies, poems, hymns, and lyrics—flowed effortlessly from his brush, numbering several hundred pieces. He also authored *Recorded Sayings* and *The Song of the Skull’s Liberation*, awakening the world with their warnings. All his works concealed wondrous efficacy, expounding the true wind of the Dao, guiding people toward goodness, and bringing great benefit to the age.

Abbot Wang Liuhui of Quanzhen Hermitage in Junzhou and others carved printing blocks to publish and disseminate his teachings far and wide. In the bingwu year, a great flood swept them away, scattering the blocks and causing their loss. Master Ever-Living of Yishui, Liu, moved by compassion, opened the path of expedient means and dispatched his disciples Xu Shoudao, Li Daowei, and Yu Wuxian to my hometown, entrusting me with a preface. They wished to commission craftsmen anew to carve the blocks and ensure the teachings’ enduring transmission—truly the intent of a benevolent heart.

I once reflected that Master Ever-True and I were from the same village, of similar age and like-minded in youth. As children, we played together; as adults, we traveled as friends. Yet in middle age, he met his teacher, studied the Dao, and shed his mortal form to ascend as a perfected being. Meanwhile, I, with graying temples and hoary hair, still toil in the arena of fame and profit, content to await my end, declining with the world—how foolish I have been!

I shall now cast off my restraints, relinquish the old ox’s love for its calf, and abandon the great rat’s fear of others’ greed. I will roam freely in the realm of self-attainment, laughing and wandering in the realm of true leisure. I will study the Master’s Way, recite his writings, and nurture the harmony of heaven to spend my remaining years. I wonder if, in days to come, the Master might recall our old companionship and deign to lend me his rosy clouds as a sash.

Alas! The Master has already taken flight as an immortal. Later scholars will never witness his steps nor hear his voice. Yet his profound mysteries, wondrous principles, and enduring example remain. By carefully savoring these writings, they may yet grasp them.

On the full moon of the first month in the dingwei year of the Dading era, this preface was written by Fan Zede Yu, Instructor of Dongmou Prefecture.

*Collected Works of Water and Clouds, Volume One*
Composed by Master Ever-True of Kunlun Mountain, Tan Chuduan

**Seven-Lawregulated Verses: Inscribed at Chaoyuan Palace in Luoyang**
The palace gates stand still, sealed in auspicious mist,
Yet ancient traces and sacred marks remain as if present.
Clouds shroud linked branches where the alchemical cauldron boils,
Rosy dawns rise from the numinous well to irrigate the elixir spring.
The sun’s essence refines the land of Huaxu,
The moon’s spirit gathers the realm of endless day.
Since the Purple Edict summoned the Perfected away,
Who now shall succeed as the Great Luo Immortal?

**Visiting Ling Mountain Temple**
Leisurely I wander clouds and waters to seek the Chan grove,
Jade-like bamboo glows thickly against emerald peaks.
The Jade Pillar Peak stands high, unstained by dust,
Ling Mountain Temple hides where few may find its realm.
White snow blends in even drifts like jade spread,
Golden blossoms scatter amidst yellow flowers.
On an autumn night by the limpid ancient pool,
Osmanthus blooms alone reveal the original heart.

**Visiting Magistrate Liu’s Garden**
A host of worthies invites me to admire the fragrant bloom,
After rain clears, I pass alone through the bright gate.
By the balustrade, peonies vie in splendor,
Around the courtyard, butterflies contend in lofty flight.
The wind stirs willow eyes with ruthless intent,
The rain washes flower hearts clean of right and wrong.
All things merge into spring’s single qi,
Selfless, it scatters its fragrance everywhere.

**Presented to the White-Haired Elder Guo of Xinzhong**
How many ever reach the white-haired elder’s state?
Birth, aging, sickness, and death mark the beginning and end.
Foul impurities and rank desires shorten lifespan,
While greed and envy turn the mind to darkness.
Love and hate make transcending the world difficult,
Desireless and passionless, one attains liberation.
Fortunate that paths to heaven and hell exist—
Sages and fools, delusion and awakening, all rest with you.

**Presented to Immortal Cheng of Yunyang**
The greatest fear in cultivation is stubborn bronze,
For one clad in stubborn bronze gains no merit.
When the heart stirs with false dust, one sinks to the underworld,
When the mind abides in purity, one walks the celestial palace.
You must emulate Yanzi’s joy in poverty,
Not crave Deng Tong’s wealth and greed.
Learn from Master Ma of Zhongnan,
Who dwelt in utter destitution within the ring.

**Presented to Immortal Zheng**
Leaving the world, he dwells in a hermitage beyond things,
Silently cultivating, erasing traces, ceasing all debate.
Wondrously he purges filth, delighting in pure poverty,
Using clarity to wash away ignorance, content with plainness.
His thatched door stands unbarred—what hinders him?
A single gourd suffices to quench greed.
Calm and still, he sits in effortless ease,
Piercing through the three lights of sun, moon, and stars.

**Presented to Young Master Han on Cultivating the Dao at Home**
Uphold truth, initiate goodness, establish the mysterious hall,
Diligently offer incense morning and evening.
Within, serve your widowed mother with filial devotion,
Without, uphold integrity to align with the Three Lights.
Always act with compassion to lift the poor and distressed,
Frequently extend mercy to relieve those in misfortune.
If one day your wisdom awakens,
You too shall return to the immortal realm.

**Presented to Disciples Anranzi and Others**
The Master’s subtle words enlighten all,
Do not idly exhaust qi and spirit.
To seek the treasures of the sea’s depths,
Refine the mountain’s summit to eliminate the slightest flaw.
The heart chasing worldly passions harms qi and fire,
The mind wandering in craving injures the spirit’s blade.
I hope you awaken early to the illusory world,
And avoid another cycle in the human realm.

**Presented to the Eighty-Year-Old Daoist Nun Yang**
Seeking the mysterious, the eighty-year-old Daoist nun Yang,
A jade-like flower blooming after autumn’s frost.
Her jade cup brims with water of purity and stillness,
Her golden censer must glow with fragrant wisdom.
Now she has secured future blessings,
Henceforth, what doubt remains of past misfortunes?
In the serene and empty hall, free from obstruction,
The precious cauldron naturally reveals rosy light.

**Inscribed at Master Kong’s Hermitage**
The empty gate stands silent, sealing the numinous spring,
Delighting in the spring’s profound mystery upon mystery.
Secluded, it often draws idle visitors,
In quietude, it shares its abode with the sleeping phoenix.
The cool and pure realm transcends the dusty path—
Only by treading here does one know another heaven exists.
If the seeker is willing to look in lowly places,
They shall suddenly behold the immortal.

**Presented to Marshal Wang of Junzhou**
Noble Wang delights in the mysterious current,
Urging me earnestly to invert the jade cup.
Goodness accumulates gradually from the heart,
Merit must be sought within one’s nature.
Benefiting others while diminishing the self reveals true principle,
Enduring insults with compassion unlocks wondrous depths.
Equanimity and harmony are the great Dao—
Three shall ascend together in the divine vessel.

**Inscribed at Yunxi Hermitage**
At Yunxi, the recluse lies amidst mist and rosy clouds,
Silently drinking the sun’s essence and moon’s radiance.
Mists disperse from the cinnabar terrace, revealing auspicious herbs,
Clouds gather around the numinous crucible, forming jade-like blooms.
The Azure Dragon exhales fire to brew golden tea,
The White Tiger digs springs to irrigate jade sprouts.
When dragon and tiger unite, the work completes nine cycles,
A single grain of the elixir holds cinnabar’s treasure.

**Expressing My Aspirations**
I admire poverty and leisure to explore the wondrous mechanism,
Thus knowing my body enters the realm of white clouds.
Carefree beyond the world, I transcend the dust’s net,
Unfettered within, I shed the garment of defilement.
Fearing harm to hidden merit, I examine my faults,
Anxious to avoid moral injury, I shun others’ blame.
When the nine-cycled cinnabar elixir is complete,
I shall invite the Three Immortals to return with me.

**Again**
Blunting sharpness, subduing strength, I become good,
Suddenly both heart and method are forgotten.
In the cauldron, the vajra flame frequently rises,
In the furnace, the prajna incense perpetually burns.
The jade elixir first blooms—only I gather it,
The immortal peach ripens—I taste it first.
Do not say the land of Huaxu is distant,
In perfect emptiness, the path is not long.

**Again**
A single shortcut leads to the immortal source,
At the cave’s mouth, numinous clouds veil the verdant peak.
When winds and waves arise, wield the sword of wisdom,
Where the mysterious waves settle, pluck the golden lotus.
The dragon subdued, it sleeps in the Li palace,
The tiger captured, it rests in the Kan chamber.
When these two are pacified, worldly affairs end,
With merit complete and conduct fulfilled, the embryonic immortal is born.

**Again**
Longing for the immortal source’s enduring scenes,
I purify the numinous land and spread jade-like fragrance.
The Red Child of the Southern Palace dwells in the cool hall,
The Black Tortoise of the Northern Sea resides in the crimson chamber.
In the Pure and Still Grotto, the White Tiger is imprisoned,
On the Effortless Mountain, the Azure Sheep are herded.
Since the clouds gathered within the cauldron,
I perpetually drink the divine nectar, lying in drunken bliss.

**Again**
The Daoist’s home is desolate and free,
Embracing weakness, following conditions, passing the years.
Against the cold, coarse robes of paper suffice,
To sate hunger, plain rice with greens will do.
Forgetting words, distant from worldly ties,
Abandoning thoughts, the Dao’s profundity grows.
Those attached to wives, children, fame, and profit—
When their limits approach, their regrets shall be as thick as hemp.

**Again**
The celestial mechanism runs deep, few comprehend it,
A single grain of the elixir is held at noon.
Mists roll back from the ancient pool on an autumn night,
Clouds gather from the green peaks in the moon’s glow.
The dragon is seized and imprisoned in the lofty cauldron,
The tiger is captured and bound in the Kan pool.

The immortal elixir is refined, transcending creation,
To hasten to Penglai Isle and pay homage to the true master.

**Again**
The wind sighs through pines, rustling and light,
Roaming beyond the world, one with the immortals.
The nature shines like the bright moon flowing through the azure sky,
The heart drifts like idle clouds across the boundless blue.
The fierce tiger is captured and imprisoned in the Kan gate,
The dragon is subdued and bound in the Li palace.
The vajra flames rise repeatedly through the celestial cycle,
Forging within the furnace a single crimson grain.

**Again**
A luminous point illumines the towering terraces,
Clearly realizing non-arising, transcending coming and going.
On the Seven Treasures Mountain, the crimson flames are extinguished,
In the sacred land of the Three Palaces, the white lotus blooms.
The purple court of mist and rosy clouds draws near,
The cloud-path to Yingzhou is left behind, never to return.
Who shares the portion of the never-night Jade Capital?
The Four Companions attend the Ever-Spring Immortal.

**Again**
A green serpent, three feet long, carried in the sleeve,
A single grain of cinnabar coalesces at the proper hour.
Mists shroud the clear deep, imprisoning the colt,
Smoke veils the verdant peaks, binding the ape.
After a thousand mornings, the dragon leaps into fire when the work is complete,
After nine revolutions, the tiger enters the pool when the merit is fulfilled.
Seizing the true creation of emptiness,
The celestial mechanism runs deep, few comprehend it.

**Again**
Desire’s cunning surpasses defilement and idle speech,
Awakening to this, one departs from all extremes.
To sever desire and forget emotion is to grasp the wondrous principle,
Smoke disperses and fire dies, attaining the profound mystery.
Mouth agape, tongue raised—how can the work be accomplished?
Thoughts arise, heart stirs—how can the path be perfected?
Cutting off worldly ties, nothing remains,
In desolate solitude and quiet simplicity, one passes the remaining years.

**Again**
True practice, true conduct, arranged in secrecy,
Ten years of diligent care, nurtured with utmost devotion.
The mind forgets worldly realms, transcending the other shore,
Worldly passions and thoughts perish, arriving at Penglai.
The buried treasure-sword’s radiance pierces the Dipper,
The pearl hidden in the clam silently nurtures the embryo.
Cultivation must rely on true creation,
To fathom creation, refine the heart to ashes.

**For Disciples**
Leaving the secular home to enter the Daoist’s,
Is like treading mist and rosy clouds from level ground.
In the world of dust, time is fleeting,
Within the immortal’s gourd, days and months stretch long.
The carefree life of drifting clouds and waters is true livelihood,
Emptiness and purity are the virtuous way of life.
Constantly observing desirelessness, worldly ties grow distant,
Unawares, the great cinnabar coalesces within the furnace.

**Again**
Hold to the One, truly abide, recognizing inner tranquility,
Diligently and arduously practice, refining the heart to uprightness.
The path to the Mystery Origin is not easy,
Yet within the square inch, no dust—this is not difficult.
In the twelve hours, remain ever vigilant,
Within the three thousand merits, do not deceive or slacken.
If you seek the path ahead without coming or going,
Deeply contemplate the view of no-self, no-person.

**Again**
Subdue strength, temper sharpness in cultivation,
Extinguish the self, subdue the heart, sever worldly ties.
Silently polish, removing cleverness and eloquence,
Drowsily forge, casting off ferocity and savagery.
Where ignorance arises, the true spirit darkens,
When softness and weakness arise, the Dao-eye brightens.
Each battle with ignorance is waged,
Each act of endurance is a victory.

**Again**
Eradicate evil, remove passions, act with goodness,
Best to forget both fame and profit together.
On the mountain’s peak, extinguish the fire of ignorance,
In the sacred chamber, constantly add the incense of prajna.
When all dust and grime are removed, the bright mirror appears,
When wasteland is cleared, the jade lotus blooms.
Do not weary of the distant path of cultivation,
For the road to emptiness is not long when fully realized.

**Again**
In cultivation, one must recognize the spirit’s source,
Recognizing the spirit’s source, a single point shines fresh.
Passions and desires forever severed, transcending the dharma realms,
Ignorance and anger extinguished, departing from heaven and humanity.
Cease the inverted delusion of clinging to existence,
Do not stir the dusty heart to taint myriad conditions.
Within the emptiness and stillness of the nature, no obstructions,
Naturally, in leisure, the embryo of the person is born.

**Again**
In the empty hall, silently burn the heart’s incense,
This is the true Daoist sanctuary of my gate.
Entering emptiness, seek freedom,
Dispelling afflictions, find coolness.
The symbols Kan and Li arrange the furnace and hearth,
The hexagrams guide the celestial cycle, refining white and yellow.
Eternally, ceaselessly, follow this practice,
When the work is complete, the nine revolutions yield lead frost.

**Again**
In cultivation, do not seek within the dharma,
Clinging to dharma in search brings no freedom.
Recognize that your own heart is the Buddha,
Why exhaust yourself in external wanderings?
The spirit’s source, wisdom’s illumination—let dust not obscure it,
In responding to things, let no thought linger.
Two paths of pure wind open the jade gate,
A single silver stream emerges from the mountain’s peak.

**Self-Reflection**
From the outset, cutting off love to practice austerity,
Holding to the One, embracing poverty, my resolve unwavering.
Bamboo hat and sheepskin are constant companions,
Tattered felt and a sack ever follow.
Rich mutton and fine wine hold no allure,
Plain rice and leftover broth suffice to stave off hunger.
A wooden bowl, newly acquired by begging,
Still the same as when I first left home.

**Expounding the Dao**
Roaming beyond the world like a cloud-and-water immortal,
A single grain of elixir severs worldly ties.
True emptiness coalesces the treasures of the Three Fields,
Wondrous function perfects the five-petaled lotus.
Fire dies, smoke disperses through forging,
Heart clear, intent still—through single-mindedness.
Carefree and unrestrained, the eternal true one,
Sailing the boundless prajna boat for ten thousand miles.

**Again**

**Wandering the Cloud-Water Path**

Cloud-water wandering, a home wherever I stay,
Careless of the sun and moon as years slip away.
In leisure, wisdom’s waters fill the golden crucible,
In stillness, the numinous field sprouts jade shoots anew.
Beneath the sea, red peonies are nurtured to bloom,
Atop the mountain, white lotuses form in the blue.
I now reveal the treasure beyond the dust—
Inherent thusness is itself the great elixir sand.

**Again**

Cloud-water wandering, an immortal beyond the world,
Leisurely and still, the original heaven unfurled.
Preserving the heart, extinguishing the self to unlock the golden chain,
Diminishing intent, forgetting passion to break the jade lotus’ stem.
On the farther shore, searching for the profound and wondrous,
Within the sacred mountain, securing a karmic bond most auspicious.
When the elixir is refined through nine revolutions, a pure breeze carries me,
Loosening the moorings, the prajna boat drifts free.

**Following the Rhyme of Master Hu Zi Jin**

Cultivation is neither easy nor hard to attain,
Beyond the shallow, nurture the true, and know the inner calm.
Hastily flee the scorching fire pit,
Early ascend the cool and serene Dao’s shore.
Constantly observe desirelessness to penetrate the profound principle,
Marvelous subtlety lies in emptiness, beyond love and stinginess.
Purity and non-action depend wholly on resolve,
Preserve the heart, weaken the self, in stillness and solitude.

**Sent to Master Yao**

Revered by all, Brother Tan stands tall,
Yet entangled in heavy sins within the net’s thrall.
Reflecting on past transgressions, karma lessens its weight,
But knowing faults yet persisting, sins accumulate.
A heart drawn to greed and desire invites disaster’s blow,
A mind attached to vanity piles sin upon woe.
Diminish, preserve, humble yourself low,
Who knows if the sages will deign to bestow?

**Hidden-Head Character Riddles**

**I**
□Robes of plain cloth weave subtle patterns deep,
□Armor of metal, golden stems take flight.
□Qi intermingles, demanding a change of shell,
□Elixir refined, one dons new raiment bright.
□Opening the true nature, every turn is right,
□Awakening to the original, all else is trite.
□Nephew studies under the master’s alchemy,
□Four-petaled lotus steps on clouds in flight.

**II**
□Head surges with a vast and numinous spring,
□Profound and limpid, it mirrors the heavens above.
□The Dao demands the severing of passion and desire,
□Forgetting realms, a thousand merits accrue.
□Grasp and seize no more, abandon errant quests,
□Return to the original, unite with nature’s true.
□Forged into a priceless chamber,
□Reunion in the capital with the wind-harmed immortal anew.

**III**
□Upright and serene, following nature’s way,
□Within, white lotuses bloom in array.
□Morning forging refines the boundless chamber,
□Resolute in true cultivation, ascending heaven’s stair.
□The Dao severs lingering passions, desires cease,
□The blade cleaves through karmic ties with ease.
□Do not cling to the numinous source’s thread,
□The spiritual embryo’s knotting comes first instead.

**Seven-Character Quatrains**

**Roaming Mount Hua**
Coarse food and patched robes mark the passing years,
High among white clouds, hidden in mist’s embrace.
Heart’s incense rises from the numinous source,
In samadhi, the lotus peak blooms ten feet wide.

**Composed at Qimen Town, Where Daily I Prepare Medicine for the Multitude**
Clever in many arts, yet feigning foolishness,
In non-action, guarding the One, nurturing the spirit pearl.
Suddenly awakened, the dream of toil and dust,
Alone I drink the wine of no-birth, a single gourd.

**Ode to the Solitary Bamboo**
A jade-green stalk rises from the fragrant thicket,
Upright in node, hollow in heart—none compare.
Enduring snow, defying frost through the years,
Naturally, from time to time, a pure breeze stirs there.

**Ode to the Moon Osmanthus**
Green leaves, supple stems, crimson buds unfold,
Spirit in every blossom, dancing in the clear wind’s hold.
With pine and bamboo, it endures the cold’s test,
Claiming the year’s glory, the work of creation’s behest.

**Ode to the Crane**
Still and solitary, facing the autumn wind,
Black and white distinct, the work of creation’s hand.
Marvel not at its thousand-year longevity,
For atop its crown, the red elixir is grand.

**The Three Teachings**
The three teachings have ever been one family,
Dao and Chan in purity differ not at all.
Confucius walked upright, penetrating the profound,
Those who awaken ride the rainbow’s call.

**Expressing My Feelings**
Not knowing to seek emptiness beyond the external,
Dragons and tigers are tamed, their power inverted.
Lazy in morning and dusk at incense and prayer,
Within the twelve hours, only the heart is worshipped there.

**Again**
Dim and silent, profound and abstruse,
In purity and non-action, guarding nature’s truth.
The true nature congeals, aided by true qi,
Boundless transformations may pierce the sky’s roof.

**Again**
Now my cloud-water path is my former vow,
Carefully observing the eight-line verse I avow.
To extend years and increase life’s span,
Refine the golden essence, recognize true compassion.

**Again**
On the twenty-ninth day of the month, I drink,
A hundred years hold thirty-six thousand scenes.
Unheard in the world are my affairs,
Returning, I enter the land of drunkenness.

**Again**
Formerly reckless, fierce, and coarse,
Today I preserve my heart, hoping karma’s weight grows less.
Within the twelve hours, ever vigilant,
Who knows if heaven and earth will grant forgiveness?

**Again**
Moths drawn to the lamp’s flame, unaware of the blaze,
Fish lured by fragrant bait—just the same.
Moths charred, fish rotted—do you know?
Better to dwell in Jetavana’s bough.

**Again**
Masters Tan, Ma, Qiu, and Liu,
Wandering freely, at ease in their practice true.

The celestial cycle refines boundless treasures,
A single radiant light is self-attained.

**Again**
Ancient Buddha’s Lingyan is my home,
A realm of cool purity, free from sorrow’s moan.
The Daoist’s livelihood holds no other task,
Only gathering the Three Lights to forge the azure haze.

**Again**
Now I see through the moth’s love for the flame,
The fish lured by bait, playing in dark waves’ game.
Foul and filthy things at root they be,
Adorned with guile, they craft illusions cunningly.

**You Huaichuan**
With a heart’s source clear, all matters cease,
Beyond this mystery, what more could one seek?
A belly vast and round, unstained by dust,
Roam freely through Huaichuan’s streams at will.

**Again**
To govern with pure virtue is to cultivate the Dao,
Loyalty, filial piety, benevolence, and compassion surpass leaving home.
Having walked this path of merit to its end,
One shall surely ascend on clouds of radiance.

**Again**
Plowing cloud-fields across three thousand miles,
The moon pierces dusk’s veil o’er a hundred thousand homes.
In the clear night, a jade-green pool gleams bright,
The clam swallows silver moonlight, birthing cinnabar’s light.

**For Zhang Dianshi**
A hundred years of time flash by in a blink,
Diligence in cultivating immortality’s pact—how could one not think?
Even if one returns as top scholar in triumph grand,
The truth dawns: yellow millet’s dream was but a fleeting strand.

**Five-Character Regulated Verse**
*For the Mother of Master Zhao of Chang’an*
Teeth and hair reborn in black,
Longevity’s three causes in her track.
Utmost sincerity follows the Dao’s friend,
Meticulous reverence serves the lofty Perfected One.
A tranquil mind tames the monkey and horse,
A pure heart gathers qi and spirit’s force.
With proper demeanor, I bow in respect,
Kowtowing to the long-lived one I protect.

**Exhortation to Cultivate the Dao**
Hear my method to cleanse the heart,
In effortless ease, its savor imparts.
Within the formless, wondrous use,
Within the formed, inner light infuses.
People are stained by desire’s embrace,
Passion arises, harming spirit and qi’s grace.
When people sever passion and desire’s chain,
Step by step, they tread the immortal’s domain.

**Five-Character Quatrain**
*Exhortation to Cultivate the Dao*

**Studying the Dao**

To study the Dao, dispel the illusory,
To refine the true, empty the void of emptiness.
The root returns to one source—
Bright moon and clear wind.

**Again**

Wine, lust, anger, and wealth all spent,
Worries, sorrows, and cares forgotten.
Clinging thoughts and loves severed,
The five-petaled jade lotus blooms fragrant.

**Again**

The Great Dao is ever pure and still,
In non-action, it guards the natural.
If the heart does not turn back,
Where can words transmit it be sought?

**Again**

Sitting alone in a ring-shaped hut,
Solitude’s purity tastes most sweet.
Effortless, with nothing to do,
Silently guarding the Three and Three.

**Again**

Gathering those *pāramitā* blossoms,
Brewing them into *prajñā* tea.
Steeped in water of purity,
After sipping, the yellow sprout appears.

**Again**

Ever seeing desire as suffering,
Tiles and pebbles turn to gold.
Seeing the body as dung and dust,
The bright moon shines on jade peaks.

**Again**

When the heart is clear and fresh,
Speech and silence harmonize spirit and qi.
Purity dissolves all sins,
Non-action unbinds all demons.

**Ode to the Dawn Rooster**

Its crow scatters the moon from the city wall,
Calling forth the sun to rise in the east.
Wondrous, this true virtue—
Awakening the old man in his dream.

**Admonition on the Brush**

Only when the brush’s dust is fully shed
Can the Dao be embraced in wordlessness.

Eating a plateful—just enough to warm the belly.
Others’ rights and wrongs matter not to me,
For I have seen through worldly affairs.
Drifting, carefree, following conditions as they come,
Freely roaming in dwelling, walking, sitting, lying.

*Two Southern Branch Songs*

Frequently trimming the candle of luminous clarity,
Diligently honing the blade of wisdom.
Ten thousand entanglements cut away, not a thread remains,
Tempering from the primal origin—spare no effort to the end.
Radiance soars above water’s depths,
Snowy waves cast from mountain peaks.
Tiger and dragon coil round the crucible,
Forging the immortal elixir,
Step by step ascending the azure heavens.

Again—
Clouds drift, the southern mountains grow still,
Wind comes, the Wei River turns cold.
Walking the waves, congealing into a single mass,
Gazing across ten thousand miles of clear sky,
So crisp and bright in this moment.
The hero’s sword rings as it leaves the scabbard,
A head rolls onto the jade platter.
A bright moon climbs the balustrade—
Only then, from this point on,
Does the heart-mind find true ease.

*Oriole’s Song*

**Living Ghosts**

Living ghosts, living ghosts—
day after day in the marketplace,
contending for fame, scrambling for gain,
clinging to fair maidens, darling sons,
casting aside the root and source.
Too late to seek deliverance,
what recourse when the final hour comes?
You’ll have no share in heaven’s ascent,
but fate will drag you down to earth.

*Bodhisattva Barbarian*

Where the blade of wisdom swings, heads roll,
rainbow light surges through the clouds’ feet.
My human heart extinguished—
why seek beyond?

White lotus blooms within fire,
dharma-endurance transcends life and death.
Patience and shame both void,
tortoise-hair and hare-horn the same.

---

**Auspicious Partridge (Eleven Songs)**

In cultivation, seek not the tiger-dragon child,
only the luminous clarity that knows the primal mechanism.
Dulled, Amitābha becomes an outer thief;
awakened, affliction is bodhi.

Constantly examine your own faults—mind grows bright;
only seeing others’ wrongs—nature turns deluded.
Shatter every bond, then rest—
in the empty hall, companion to the Muni.

---

Again—
In cultivation, seek not the tiger-dragon child,
fire extinguished, smoke dispersed, wealth and desire left behind.
Within, refine qi and spirit to ninefold transmutation;
without, purge impurities, expel the Three Corpses.

Dwell in stillness, speak not of others’ faults;
abide in purity, search only your own transgressions.
Keep the spiritual root unobstructed—
naturally, you’ll realize the fruit of buddhahood.

---

Again—
In cultivation, frequently trim the lamp within your nature,
illuminating the long-darkened gloom.
Let go of every attachment, every thing—
dull and silent, words cease.

Transcending the mundane to enter sageliness is not by my doing;
hell and heaven lie entirely within you.
Only one true path remains—
dwell always, firmly sealing the four city gates.

---

Again—
Each pursues the Dao, yet craves rank flesh,
drunk on wine, infatuated with flowers, bound by sin.
The heart’s craving for flesh harms living beings;
the mind’s greed for love erodes the root.

Boasting of medicinal arts, claiming mastery,
who believes in the golden precepts’ secret mystery?
When you awaken to emptiness, rest—
lay it all down and cultivate immortality.

---

Again—
Cultivate the heart like cold ashes,
release delusion, greed, anger, desire, wealth.
How can self and other yield the fruit of the Dao?
How can right and wrong give birth to the true embryo?

When ignorance is extinguished, ascend the golden palace;
when passions and desires are forgotten, bow at the jade steps.
Refinement must end in smoke and fire’s demise—
for where the heart is low, Penglai appears.

---

Again—
The original true nature is the mystery’s mechanism,
grasped only in luminous clarity’s awakening.
Fire extinguished, smoke dispersed—the great medicine forms;
realms forgotten, mind exhausted—bodhi appears.

Leisurely stillness is the true immortal’s path,
solitude and non-action the ladder from the world.
Not a single dharma arises, no obstructions—
cultivation is only this.

---

Again—
In cultivation, sing the falling-flower lotus,
diminish and diminish, idle and idle, follow nature.
When the sun rises, speak not of others’ faults;
throughout the day, frequently correct your own bias.

Do not stray from the square inch to seek the elixir;
do not wander outside to find the wondrous mystery.
Keep the spirit-terrace empty of all things—
then the ninefold transmutation births the embryonic immortal.

---

Again—
Cultivation is neither easy nor hard,
responding to things with compassion, recognizing inner stillness.
Where the mind harbors dust, mountains become markets;
where the heart holds no affairs, markets become mountains.

Constantly till three plots of pure fields,
steadfastly guard one chamber of non-action.
Earth endures, heaven lasts—devote yourself to one aim,
and naturally the purple-golden elixir coalesces.

---

Again—
Do not say cultivation is easy to uphold,
diminishing and preserving, fearing hindrance and conflict.

Again—
Two meals—beware lest they encroach upon Dao-friends;
a single coin—fear it may harm the realm of mystery.
Among crowds, guard your speech and forget pride;
in solitude, rein in the mind and halt its gallop.
Through the twelve hours, constantly turn the light inward,
still doubting whether hidden scrutiny reveals selflessness.

To Master Wang of Yun’an:
Master Wang, secluded in deep retreat, dines on fine fare,
protecting the numinous root and guarding inner stillness.
Where emotion lingers, mountains become markets;
where desire is absent, markets become mountains.
Nurture the spirit with constant warmth,
and when qi-refinement is complete, repel heat and cold.
Unwavering from start to finish,
naturally the precious *langgan* coalesces.

To Master Guo:
Still the heart, reduce affairs to nourish the root-source,
abiding in tranquil emptiness and guarding the natural.
Accumulate virtue and benevolent influence, following Confucius and Mencius;
seek seclusion and lofty purity, emulating Yan and Yuan.
In samādhi, gaze upon the bright moon of a mid-autumn night;
in wondrous subtlety, feel the mysterious breeze of a ninth-month summer.
Who can match the lute, poetry, wine, and books?
This rustic fellow often resembles a dragon in slumber.

Gazing Toward Penglai, Five Poems:

The true Great Dao—
diminish and diminish in cultivation.
Wherever you go, people revere and offer sustenance,
yet gaining advantage is but losing advantage,
step by step sinking into the mire.

For the impoverished man—
abide in tranquility, do not stray.
Outwardly, let your demeanor inspire awe;
inwardly, silently gather the numinous fungus.
Soon you will meet your master’s appointed time.

Again—

Hear this counsel—
few matters need the lord’s attention.
Striving endlessly for all things harms only yourself;
gaining advantage is but losing advantage.
Cleverness cannot compare to simplicity.

In true cultivation,
seek nothing beyond the heart.
Only the present moment lies before your eyes;
naturally, vexations will not follow.
Step by step, enter non-action.

Again—

Walk the Great Dao,
recognize Kan and Li.
At the inverted point where the single spark arises,
twofold signs reveal their secrets.
The mystery is not hard to know.

Seek not without—
awaken to your own bodhi.
Within the body of form, refine through tempering;
on the path of non-action, realize the Muni.
Soon you will mount the clouds.

Again—

The wondrous perfection of the Complete Truth—
no self, no others.
No action, no striving, beyond sight and sound,
humble, gentle, and yielding, without estrangement.
In solitude, uphold pure poverty.

In the profoundest depths,
each attainment is a fine cause.
The single spark of non-arising is true freedom;
serene and ever still, originally real.
When merit is full, join the immortals’ ranks.

Again—

Perpetual Truth’s Child,
daily turns in ceaseless seeking.
Follow your lot, follow conditions to dissolve past karma;
idle sorrows and idle vexations all cease at once.
The bright moon shines over the mountain’s peak.

Ever clear and still,
no attainment, no cultivation.
Free, beyond the bounds of cause and effect,
carefree and transcendent, escape the sinking stream.
When merit is full, reach Penglai’s shores.

Three Poems on the Flower-Strewn Path

Through the master’s grace, I crossed the bitter sea,
left the worldly to explore the profound mystery.
Suddenly dwelling in the land of joy,
I recognized poverty as leisure’s way.
Right and wrong, self and others—
what matter wise or foolish?
Step by step on the cool, clear path,
trusting in free wandering,
who knows such serenity?
No heart to gaze afar at immortals—
when the time comes, follow conditions as they flow.

Yao’s reign brought harvests rich and full,
thanks to august Heaven.
Water and clouds my livelihood,
seeking but a single coin.
Diminishing, ever at ease in idleness,
silent and without striving,
letting years and months stretch on unbroken.

Again—

As the Double Ninth arrives,
clouds and waters drift to the edge of the sky.
Dao-friends invite me to drink,
admiring the yellow chrysanthemums.
Especially for this refined gathering,
gazing south toward emerald mists and rosy clouds.
Eyes straining through the mountain haze,
dimly discerned in the distance—
immortal dwellings deep in auspicious clouds.
Freely, merrily, drinking and reveling,
laughter and boasts rise like leaping fish.
Before the goblet, only wine brings joy—
what more could one desire?
Floating gold ripples,
silently gathering the numinous blossom.
Drinking done, yet urged again,
no return until drunk,
as the bright moon first climbs the window gauze.

Again—

Above, no tiled roof of three,
below, not a plow’s worth of land.

A true livelihood of water and clouds—
just follow conditions as they come.
Hands outstretched in the street,
alms sought from those with karmic affinity.
This "affinity" bears the hidden meaning.

Returning alone at dusk,
ten thousand miles of cloudless sky—
lying down to hear tigers roar and apes cry.
Leisurely, at ease, boundless true joy,
a surging spring of numinous qi.

The true fire descends in the crucible,
eternally congealing the lead.
Tiger and dragon coil and entwine,
true essence rooting in the source.

Sitting in silent non-action,
alone guarding the solitary peak—
a single bright moon flows across the heavens.

*Five "Pounding Silk" Songs*

*Pounding Silk*—
what does it hold?
Past sins and karmic debts
slowly ground away.
*Luoli suo, lisuo luo.*
From the first attainment,
recognizing *pāramitā*.
Sense pleasures and wealth shattered—
like moths to a flame.
*Luoli suo, lisuo luo.*

Again—

Listen to the explanation,
this "wind brother."
Usually just so much *luoli luo*.
*Luoli suo, lisuo luo.*
A few words—
no need for more.
When the wise understand,
they laugh *hehe*.
*Luoli suo, lisuo luo.*

The pure Dharma transcends the mundane,
the divine vessel steadily ferries across sinking waves.
*Luoli suo, lisuo luo.*
Act swiftly,
emerge from the river of delusion.
If they still do not awaken,
time slips by in vain.
*Luoli suo, lisuo luo.*

Again—

Fleeting glory,
a dream in Nanke.
Years flash like lightning,
rolling down the wheel’s slope.
*Luoli suo, lisuo luo.*
Break free early,
escape the whirlpool.
Sun and moon race like shuttles,
two losses in a row.
*Luoli suo, lisuo luo.*

Again—

The wind-borne singer chants,
a song to shatter delusion.
Turn your heart—
meet Maitreya with me.
*Luoli suo, lisuo luo.*
Ten *Pounding Silk* songs,
must harmonize.
Kindness, love, and desire—
these are the demons of enmity.
*Luoli suo, lisuo luo.*

*Three "Han Palace Spring" Songs*

In the *jiazi* celestial cycle,
under a radiant imperial age,
immortals descend to the world.
The immortal master secretly dispatched me,
thus I journeyed east through mist and waves.
Mountains distant, roads far,
crossings arduous—how could I refuse the long trek?
Only this念念:
each person yet unenlightened,
vainly clinging to household schemes.

The wheel of rebirth is bitter—
awaken and reflect.
Observe the ancients’ methods,
how they broke free.
Sever worldly ties,
gradually drawing near the profound Dao.
With merit complete and qi congealed,
soon the body ascends to immortality.
Returning thereafter,
phoenix and crane guide me
to the true assembly of Penglai.

Again—

Seeking the wuwei,
delighting in leisure within leisure,
just this little remains.
Focus on the present—
past and future, let them be.
Walk always in openness,
far from wealth and desire,
from human right and wrong.
Recently thus,
inner joy untroubled,
not a thread of attachment to the world.

Drowsy and silent—
yet within the formless,
grasp the true root.
Lucid and free,
no use, no action, no holding.
Everywhere turning back to reflect,
naturally the principle shines,
radiant in every encounter.
Who understands?
The clear wind and bright moon—
only two people know their depth.

Again—

Admiring poverty and leisure,
I tempered strength, blunted sharpness,
embraced softness and harmony.
Worldly ties suddenly cast off,
the lamp of wisdom brightly lit the spirit-chamber.
The seven gates turned inward,
adorned with seven treasures,
secretly arrayed.
Taming the ape and horse,
cunning and cleverness arise—
refine them into another path.

Guard purity and spontaneity,
abide in wuwei, ever good,
a single stick of heart-incense.
In peace and joy,
jade liquid flows in jeweled cups.
Cloud companions, rosy friends,
laughing and clamoring,
gold and jade chiming.
When people depart,
clouds disperse, mist clears—
the limpid moon fills the empty hall.

*Nine "Longing for Immortals" (Longing Everlasting) Songs*

Dawn longs for immortals,
dusk longs for immortals,
yearning for the true master four or five years.
Only fearing merit incomplete.

Merit must be complete,
conduct must be complete,
merit and conduct both perfected—
a great immortal.
Carrying clouds, returning to the grotto-heaven.

Again—

The mind races outward—
painful whips in hand,
yet with tempered nature, the path is never lost.
By fragrant streams, lush grasses thrive.

The thorn returns,
the ox follows,
as the bright moon hangs high, illuminating the ancient dyke.
When neither man nor ox is seen.

Again—

Gold must be plentiful,
silver must be plentiful,
and the toil of servants, horses, and fields—all must be plentiful.
Yet at departure, karmic debts grow heavier still.

What of poverty?
What of wealth?
With a heart untouched by all things, what then?
What can the future do to me?

Again—

The Daoist’s heart—
dwells in no-heart,
a carefree, unfettered, pure and tranquil heart.
A drifting, cloud-and-water heart.

The heart for fame and gain,
the heart of endless greed,
day and night tormented, enslaved—
when will it ever rest?

Again—

The heart of cultivation,
the heart of forbearance,
a single expanse of cold, empty detachment.
A leisurely, useless heart.

The heart of wrath extinguished,
the heart of desire cast away,
solitude and poverty align with the sage’s heart.
The unborn reveals the original heart.

Again—

Fair as blossoms in bloom,
do not wait for fragrance to scatter with the evening wind.
Only at the end is emptiness realized.

Profoundly search,
break free from the mundane cage,
with fierce resolve, burn all to ash—rise as a world-transcending hero.
When merit is complete, ascend the Three Isles’ peaks.

Again—

Encountering the wind immortal,
receiving the hidden teaching,
like tumbleweed on clouds and water, ever at ease.
The numinous brightness reveals the original source.

Refine true lead,
irrigate the pure spring—
know that within the gourd lies another heaven.
Attain carefree serenity.

Obtaining return to nothingness,
merging with emptiness—
still and limpid, as if not there.
From the primordial beginning, nothing more.

Principles clarified, emptiness realized,
a single numinous source truly like void.
Radiance pierces the great void.

Again—

Attaining the profound mystery,
awakening to the Three-in-Three,
fire extinguished, smoke dispersed—wind’s harm silenced.
In serene obscurity, preserve the Jade Lad.

Pursue leisurely ease,
recognize pure simplicity—
one nature wholly like the moon at due south.
Limpid, the azure pool appears.

*Remembering the Prince—Seven Poems*

The divine boat steadies its course through dark currents,
bright moon’s glow—destiny fulfills itself.
Two masters nod in silent accord.
There is reason:
ten thousand kalpas of rebirth end here.

Again—

Who truly masters the heart’s submission?
The crimson phoenix drives it to drink from jade rivers.
Guiding the infant, laughing, they dance as one.
Trimming the silver lamp,
each thing reveals itself at dawn’s window.

Again—

From the first attainment, grace flows freely,
taming tortoise and snake to dwell in stillness.
A thousand days—elixir complete, forever secured.
What fine cause!
Carefree and at ease, all affairs cease.

Again—

Heart free of affairs, qi and spirit harmonize,
unaware, joyful words overflow.
The sword of Dao-steel, ground ever finer.
Wind’s harm, brother—
cut out the tongue, drive the demons away.

Again—

Worldly dust clings with wealth and desire’s suffering,
love of fleeting splendor enslaves this body.
Awaken to the numinous source’s single truth.
Cut off greed and wrath—
then you are one who has reached the shore’s freedom.

Again—

Nothing, nothing—no, there is something, yet nothing,
awakening to nothingness, one is no longer foolish.
Days, months, years wear away the coarse and strong.
Behold the primordial beginning—
ten thousand rays of rosy light gather the jewel.

Again—

Vast, the bitter sea stretches boundless,
endless deluded fish sink into black abyss.
I cast a golden hook to catch the destined.
The destined are drawn—
led aboard the divine boat to pluck jade lotuses.

*Six Poems to the Tune of "Magnolia with Reduced Characters"*

The gate of Complete Reality,
still and pure, without contrivance.
Neither easy nor hard—
wealth, desire, and ignorance all congeal the elixir.

True dragon, true tiger,
realms extinguished, mind forgotten—knowing its place.
Lead and mercury transmit,
their union must transcend all boundaries.

Again—

Carefree and at ease,
coming and going without hindrance.
A single expanse of numinous emptiness,
everywhere round and bright, nothing obstructed.

No division of inner and outer,
luminous through the sands, embracing the Dharma-realm.
Universally illuminating, selfless—
like the bright moon in autumn’s high vault.

Again—

Heart mad, intent playful,
hard to discern truth from falsehood within.
Intent playful, heart mad—
summoning all life’s sins and transgressions.

Heart calmed, intent stilled,
within stillness, wisdom’s power shines clearly.
Intent stilled, heart calmed—
the Dao naturally returns, spirit naturally numinous.

Again—

Meeting yet not awakening,
alas, the keen-witted chase desire away.
Now, time slips by—
how can I bear this?

If one day you arrive,
regret comes late—embrace the profound Dao.
Return early to cultivation,
avoid wandering the three paths and six destinies.

Again—

A skin-bag of water and clouds,
like water, like clouds—ever at ease.
At ease, a leisurely person,
in leisure, seeking the body beyond things.

Act or dwell as you will,
beyond form, true emptiness is cultivated in leisure.
To find true emptiness—
only in the deepest stillness of South Mountain.

Again—

Where the dust-heart arises,
the path of carefree clouds and water is blocked.
When the dust-heart does not rise,
form and appearance return to emptiness—monkey and horse subdued.

Now, seeing through—
preserve heaven’s truth, pass time in leisure.
To know heaven’s truth—
a body forged of white jade and yellow gold.

*To the Tune of "Spring in Wuling"*
*For Daoist Li, Breaking the Character*

The sun urges you, yet you do not heed,
beneath it, ever more frantic in greed.
Within, often turning, you wound yourself—
how could you ever reflect thus?

Nurture the numinous root, firmly secure it,
turn your gaze inward, let it shine.
Idly drifting, all affairs forgotten—
within, the immortal’s incense burns hot.

*To the Tune of "Southern Village"*

Chasing nothing in all things,
the hare and man alike fret over honor and disgrace.
Worldly cunning and schemes—all set aside.
Rest, rest—
following others’ whims brings no freedom.

Best to imprison the self,
fall into disarray, wander clouds and waters as fate allows.
Begging to preserve the heart, dissolve old sins—
cultivate, cultivate—
like the inescapable end of life’s limit.

*To the Tune of "Eternal Joy"*

To Marshal Wang the Third of Junzhou

Wandering free and at ease,
treading the path with steadfast calm—
let clouds drift, let waters flow.
Fallen into careless indulgence,
hair unkempt, face unwashed,
day after day as if drunk.
Drifting, drifting, carefree and idle,
roaming without a tether,
coming or going, nothing to bind.
Seeking scraps to fill the belly,
wherever night falls, sleep comes unbound.

None have awakened—
all their cultivation,
self-imposed, hard to sever.
Desire knows no shore,
torment in the bitter sea—
when will birth and death end?
A straw cloak, a bamboo hat,
following fate as it comes,
such is the Daoist’s livelihood.
You and I, still lost in delusion,
unwilling to let go—
just remain as you are.

Twelve Poems to the Tune of "Treading the Grass"

A cloud-and-water idler,
indulgent in plain cloth.
Roaming beyond the world,
treading mist and rosy clouds.
With heart preserved, begging alms
from dawn to dusk,
door to door, bowing in assent.

Water still, clouds at rest,
not swayed by others’ drift.
Mist scatters, fire fades—
the joy of cool clarity.
This journey to the sacred realm
returns once more to emptiness.
Staff in hand, alone I climb
the road to Chang’an.

Against repeated warnings, the wise remain unwise—
words left behind, mere traces of advice.
Yet in those words, only this plea:
*Turn back, cultivate anew*—
never once did they heed the call.

Awaken early to the wheel’s turning,
seek swiftly the path of escape.
Day and night, the two wheels hasten—
this life’s glory and rank, a debt from past lives,
but where will the fruit of the next life lead?

---

Forsaking the worldly, cultivating the Way,
transcending dust to return to simplicity.
Serene and still, thoughts forgotten,
the mad monkey and restless horse locked in an empty room—
only the luminous source, a single point, held fast.

Seek not the golden elder,
search not for dragon and tiger.
In pure leisure, wander freely.
A wisdom-wind scatters the clouds atop the ridge,
one moon illuminates the path to Caoxi.

---

Step by step, no birth—
affinity draws near to Chan and the Dao.
Illuminating the hidden, harmonizing with *Zhuangzi* and *Laozi*.
For ten years, the wind immortal sought the primordial,
now at last, the cloud-path beckons early.

Awakened to the true self,
boundless treasures within—
why craft the fruits of karmic leakage?
A life of ease, my family’s way,
carefree and open, my gate’s virtue.

---

Having attained the cultivation of truth,
one must delve into the mysteries of the profound.

All matters in the heart, forgotten and cast aside.
By the master’s wondrous guidance, the primordial origin is realized—
a single point of radiance rises atop the mountain.
A life of carefree wandering,
a livelihood of water and clouds.
Roaming freely, at ease within the red dust,
lords and nobles, do not marvel at this wind-borne man—
ordinary as this, merely so.

---

Foolish and simple,
wordless, speechless.
Ashamed of vain distinctions idly made.
From now on, no more running outward—
within, the subtlest wonder favors the clumsy.
Gather the spirit, roll up the scroll,
conceal brilliance, erase traces.
All vexations born of emptiness cease at once.
In Jetavana’s garden, plant jade blossoms—
a single fragrant golden lotus takes form.

---

No sooner do spring flowers appear
than autumn’s moon arrives.
Spring flowers, autumn moon—when will they end?
I urge you: awaken swiftly, do not waste time.
Within the gourd, another fine season awaits.
Sever love, transcend the dust—
be fierce and resolute.
Refine primordial yang, delve into the mysteries’ secrets.
Polish the spirit-pearl, let it not grow dim—
no coming, no going, beyond birth and death.

---

Endure humiliation, eat plain fare,
forever forsake impure wine.
Cleanse the heart, purify the mind, forget all existence.
Increase and decrease—emptiness is realized,
calm and steady, no other path.
Still and clear,
enduring as heaven and earth.
Hold fast to spring flowers and autumn moon.
Press onward, unshaken and upright,
silent and wordless, lips sealed.

A single mystery-pearl,
long shrouded in darkness.
Greed, wrath, and delusion stain it—hard to dissolve.
Sudden cultivation washes it clean, never to dim;
the wheel of rebirth and death poses no obstacle.
Hasten in practice, never slacken,
endure with unyielding patience.
When the heart is fully realized, where lies the return?
A crane leads through colored clouds to Penglai’s gathering.

*For Zhao Liushi of Xingping*

A hundred years of glory,
stars shift, light fades.
The human body scarce endures from dawn to dusk.
Kindness and love now gathered empty,
the final hour soon parts all.
Awaken early to rebirth’s terror,
startled by life’s sorrow.
Sever love, forsake attachment, grasp the mystery’s secrets.
Be fierce and resolute, enter the pure void—
the wind-borne poet grants you the moon of an open heart.

*For Lord Xu of Jingzhao*

The heart’s sacred field,
never swept or tended.
Dust and grime long darken it, wild grasses grow.
The spirit-spring scatters, fails to congeal—
how then to forge the treasure of long life?
Clouds and waters seek truth,
carefree, they wander in search of the Dao.
To leave home is to leave sorrow behind.
If wisdom awakens and the heart rests,
you’ll drink aged pántáo on a solitary peak.

*For Marshal Wang the Third*

I bow to you, Lord Wang,
brief words I offer.
Frost touches your temples now in twilight years.
When will clinging to love and kindness cease?
A healthy, idle body—best to still the heart.
Profound truths lie hidden,
worldly cares are upside-down.
In solitude and ease, delve into the mystery’s depths.
Walk with water and clouds to seek Danyang,
drink aged pántáo on a solitary peak.

*For Wang Silang of Xunzhou*

Brother in virtue arrives, speaking of your depths—
I hear and suddenly sigh in admiration.
One mother’s three branches betray long-held bonds,
how could the heart bear such change?
Regret past wrongs, amend conduct with skillful means.
Wisdom awakens, understanding dawns—
come swiftly to meet face-to-face.
With you, elder brother, I’ll feast in joyful countenance.
Should even slight discord arise, the Wind Master will resolve it,
surely smoothing all entanglements.
Water and clouds depart—no more parting meetings.

*To the tune "Sand of the Washing Stream"*
*Farewell to Lord Jia*

Clouds and waters drift beyond the mundane,
fishing alone with a line from the great divine boat.
Lost in the bitter sea of delusion, yet never swallowing the hook.

Returning to the jade-green waves, homeward bound,
reuniting with Ma, Qiu, Liu in the homeland’s mountains.
A jade flask of golden elixir feasts the immortal companions.

*Sent to Lord Lu*

The Master of Long Life composed "Courtyard Full of Fragrance,"
in praise of Dao and Chan, sent to aid the karmic affinity of Lord Lu Wude.

The Chan lineage of Śākyamuni,
the Daoist Patriarch Lord Lao,
Lü, Zhong, Hai, and Chan illumine heaven.
Chongyang established the teaching,
spreading good affinity by the Eastern Sea.
Only to deliver Qiu, Liu, Tan, and Ma,
branching into separate streams—Wang and Hao first transmitted.
Henceforth they depart,
gathering on the Ten Isles in immortal assembly,
where cloud companions unite in nature’s harmony.

Attaining immortality—
neither difficult nor easy.
Eight hundred deeds of cultivation,
three thousand merits fulfilled.
Awaiting the purple decree from celestial script,
when nature and life are whole.
To emerge from the shell of yin and yang,
ever unstained, all things without flaw.
Truly enlightened,
tortoise and serpent entwined,
yin exhausted, one ascends to the primordial origin.

*End of the Lower Scroll of the Water and Cloud Collection*

*Postscript:*
#1 This tune pattern should be "Treading the Sand in Shifted Mode."
#2 This lyric was composed by Liu Chuxuan, not by Master Tan.

Amid heaven and earth, humans stand—
round of head, square of foot,
bearing consciousness, containing emotion,
endowed with the essence of the Five Phases,
crowned as the spirit of all things.
Buddha-nature and immortal potential lie within,
alchemical furnace and elixir hearth all prepared.

Should one cast aside cravings,
forsake frivolity,
sever greed,
renounce fame and profit,
and still the breath in tranquil emptiness,
then may one attain longevity and enduring vision.

The immortal Master Tan of Changzhen,
by virtue of karmic affinity,
in his prime encountered the Patriarch Chongyang.
With Danyang, Changsheng, and Changchun, he shared the same master.
Later, following the Perfected One,
he journeyed west to Bianliang,
where the oral transmission was bestowed.
Thereafter, in Luochuan,
he accumulated merit and cultivated conduct,
first transcending the world to ascend in truth.

His surviving recorded words and verses,
though but a few hundred,
all enfold wondrous efficacy,
probing the workings of creation.
Entitled *Water and Cloud Collection*,
they have long circulated throughout the land.
Yet in the bingwu year,
a great flood in Jun Prefecture
washed away the printing blocks.

Upon hearing this,
the immortal and long-lived Master Liu
was deeply grieved.
He promptly ordered craftsmen
to re-engrave them at the Quanzhen Hall in Donglai.
Now, after years of warfare,
none in the realm remain intact.

Lu Qian, styled Gaoyou, and his wife Meng Changshan,
their entire household diligently devoted to the Dao,
traveled between Huai and Chu,
seeking the Perfected One’s lost manuscripts.
At last, from a disciple’s keeping—
as if by divine bestowal—
they recovered the complete volume.
Fearing this text might vanish forever,
they once more commissioned its carving and printing
at the Western Hermitage in Shanyang City.
Truly, one sees how deeply Master Gao cherishes the teachings.

Alas! The Perfected One ascended long ago,
and such writings can never be recovered.
Having seen the preface composed by my late father,
I was further entrusted to append this postscript.
Thus, despite my crude and barren words,
I offer this account.

One day, as I was compiling and arranging the *Pearl and Jade Collection*—a gathering of immortal-descended verses and hymns—suddenly, banners tall as forests and standards grand as clouds stood arrayed before my humble gate. Startled, I rose to greet the visitors at my door, only to find it was Master Xiao, come once more to cast his gaze upon me. We bowed and entered together, whereupon he addressed me, saying:

“Recently, a fellow Daoist, Zhang Zhiquan, journeyed thousands of *li* without regard for distance to bring me *The Water and Cloud Collection*, a work compiled by Master Tan, the Long-Realized One, during his lifetime. Though I am unlearned in letters and unworthy of my place in the teaching, I hold it in deep reverence. Yet after repeated wars and fires, nearly all the printing blocks of the profound and wondrous writings of the Complete Perfection tradition have been burned to ashes. Only this collection survives, fortunately preserved within a wall by some devoted soul. If we do not carve new blocks and disseminate it widely, I fear it may vanish entirely, leaving future seekers of the Dao with nothing to study or seek. I beg you to compose a preface for its reprinting.”

I replied, “In the past, the father and son scholars of Dongmou, Fan the Rectifier of Learning—men of towering talent, ardent devotion, and vast learning—have already written a preface for it. How dare I presume to add anything?” Though I repeatedly declined, I could not escape his earnest request. Thus, I offer these scattered words merely to fulfill his noble command.

On the Double-Yang Festival of the *jichou* year.

chunks.original_text: 水云集 经名：水云集。 金谭处端述。 三卷。 底本出处：《正统道藏》太平部。 水云集序 东牟，古牟子之国，齐之大郡也。 户口浩繁，人性质朴。 东连沧海，烟浪云涛，浩渺无涯，不知其几万里。 南揖昆箭，层峦垒嶂，峻极于天，不知其几千丈。 海山锺秀，人杰地灵，异人名士，代不乏人。 宜乎真人仙子，相继而生也。 谭公先生，名处端，号长真子，吾乡大族也。 生而颖悟，识度不凡，善草隶书，为人刚正有操行，乡里敬惮之。 大定丁亥岁，重阳悯化妙行真人，飞锡东来，仙游海上，以往契夙缘，访寻知友。 於吾乡得丹阳子马公、长真子谭公，於东莱掖水得长生子刘公，又於登州栖霞得长春子丘公。 结为方外眷属，所谓谭马丘刘是也。 相从真人之游，西抵夷门。 真人付以口诀，嘱以后事，厌世而上升。 四子殡葬礼终，挈徒而西，至终南山，即真人之旧隐。 传袭其道，十有余年。 自时厥后，各从所之。
chunks.translated_text:
**The Water and Cloud Collection**

*Scripture Title:* *The Water and Cloud Collection*. Composed by Tan Chuduan of the Jin dynasty. Three juan in length. Source text from the *Zhengtong Daoist Canon*, Taiping Section.

**Preface to The Water and Cloud Collection**

Dongmou was an ancient state of the Muzi, a major commandery of Qi. Its households were vast, and its people simple and unadorned. To the east, it bordered the Bohai Sea, where misty waves and surging clouds stretched boundless, extending for tens of thousands of *li*. To the south, it faced the Kun and Jian mountains, their layered peaks towering into the heavens, rising for thousands of *zhang*. With such a convergence of sea and mountain brilliance, the land was blessed with exceptional talent, and eminent figures and scholars emerged in every generation. It was only fitting that perfected beings and immortals would arise in succession.

Master Tan, styled Chuduan and known as Master Ever-True, hailed from a prominent family of our homeland. From birth, he was keenly perceptive, possessing an extraordinary bearing. Skilled in cursive and clerical script, he was upright and principled, earning the respect and awe of his village. In the *dinghai* year of the Dading era, the Perfected One of Wondrous Conduct and Compassionate Transformation, Chongyang, arrived in the east, his pilgrim’s staff alighting upon the shores. Drawn by past karmic affinities, he sought out old friends. In our homeland, he encountered Master Danyang (Ma), Master Ever-True (Tan), in Donglai Yishui, Master Ever-Living (Liu), and in Dengzhou Qixia, Master Ever-Spring (Qiu). They became a spiritual family beyond the world, known as the Four Masters: Tan, Ma, Qiu, and Liu. Together, they followed the Perfected One’s travels, journeying west to Yimen. There, the Perfected One entrusted them with oral instructions, charged them with future affairs, and then departed this world to ascend as an immortal. After the four completed the burial rites, they led their disciples west to Zhongnan Mountain, the former retreat of the Perfected One. There, they transmitted and inherited his Dao for over a decade. Thereafter, each went their separate ways.

chunks.original_text: 长真先生往来於洛川之上，行化度人，从其教者，所至云集。 其述作赋咏，举笔即成，诗颂词章，仅数百篇。 又述《语录》，《骷髅落魄歌》，警悟世人。 皆包藏妙用，敷畅真风，引人归善，甚有益於时也。 浚州全真庵主王琉辉等，镂板印行，广传四方。 值丙午岁，大水漂没，其板散亡。 掖水长生先生刘公，运慈悲心，开方便路，遣门人徐守道、李道微、于悟仙等，诣吾乡属余为序，欲再命工发椠以永其传，可谓仁人之用心也。 窃尝谓长真先生与余同乡里，年相若而志颇同，幼为儿童之戏，长为朋友之游。 而先生中年遇师学道，蝉蜕登真。 余苍颜华发，尚区区於名利之场，甘分待终，随物衰谢，何其愚也。 余将掣肘，捐老牛舐犊之爱，去硕鼠畏人之贪，逍遥於自得之乡，笑傲於真闲之境。 学先生之道，诵先生之文，高养天和以寄余生。 未审先生异日有旧游之念，肯乞飞霞佩乎。 呜呼，先生已羽化矣。 后之学者，不能见先生之步趋，闻先生之謦欬。 其玄机妙旨，遗范余风，详味斯文则可矣。 大定丁未岁正月望日，东牟州学正范择德裕序。 水云集卷上 昆仑山长真子谭处端述

Master Ever-True wandered along the Luo River, transforming and delivering people through his teachings. Wherever he went, followers gathered like clouds. His compositions—odes, rhapsodies, poems, hymns, and lyrics—flowed effortlessly from his brush, numbering several hundred pieces. He also authored *Recorded Sayings* and *The Song of the Skull’s Liberation*, awakening the world with their warnings. All his works concealed wondrous efficacy, expounding the true wind of the Dao, guiding people toward goodness, and bringing great benefit to the age.

Abbot Wang Liuhui of Quanzhen Hermitage in Junzhou and others carved printing blocks to publish and disseminate his teachings far and wide. In the bingwu year, a great flood swept them away, scattering the blocks and causing their loss. Master Ever-Living of Yishui, Liu, moved by compassion, opened the path of expedient means and dispatched his disciples Xu Shoudao, Li Daowei, and Yu Wuxian to my hometown, entrusting me with a preface. They wished to commission craftsmen anew to carve the blocks and ensure the teachings’ enduring transmission—truly the intent of a benevolent heart.

I once reflected that Master Ever-True and I were from the same village, of similar age and like-minded in youth. As children, we played together; as adults, we traveled as friends. Yet in middle age, he met his teacher, studied the Dao, and shed his mortal form to ascend as a perfected being. Meanwhile, I, with graying temples and hoary hair, still toil in the arena of fame and profit, content to await my end, declining with the world—how foolish I have been!

I shall now cast off my restraints, relinquish the old ox’s love for its calf, and abandon the great rat’s fear of others’ greed. I will roam freely in the realm of self-attainment, laughing and wandering in the realm of true leisure. I will study the Master’s Way, recite his writings, and nurture the harmony of heaven to spend my remaining years. I wonder if, in days to come, the Master might recall our old companionship and deign to lend me his rosy clouds as a sash.

Alas! The Master has already taken flight as an immortal. Later scholars will never witness his steps nor hear his voice. Yet his profound mysteries, wondrous principles, and enduring example remain. By carefully savoring these writings, they may yet grasp them.

On the full moon of the first month in the dingwei year of the Dading era, this preface was written by Fan Zede Yu, Instructor of Dongmou Prefecture.

*Collected Works of Water and Clouds, Volume One*
Composed by Master Ever-True of Kunlun Mountain, Tan Chuduan

chunks.original_text: 七言律诗 题洛阳朝元宫 宫门寂寂锁祥烟，古迹灵踪尚俨然。 云罩连枝烹药鼎，霞生灵井溉丹泉。 日魂炼就华胥国，月魄收将不夜天。 紫诏师真归去后，未知孰继大罗仙。 游灵山寺 闲闲云水访禅林，密密琅玕映碧岑。 玉柱峰高尘不染，灵山寺隐境难寻。 媾交白雪匀铺玉，间隔黄花乱点金。 清彻古潭秋静夜，桂华独现本来心。 游刘公花园 众贤邀我赏芳菲，雨霁晴明独过扉。 倚槛牡丹争秀丽，绕庭蛱蝶斗高飞。 风吹柳眼无情意，雨洗花心绝是非。 万物尽成春一气，无私普布吐馡馡。 赠新中郭四翁 几人到得白头翁，生老痾沉是始终。 浊秽腥膻除寿算，怪贪嫉妬转昏蒙。 有憎有爱难超世，无欲无情定脱空。 幸有天堂地狱路，圣凡迷悟总由公。 赠云阳程仙 修行大畏是顽铜，如着顽铜没行功。 心起妄尘沉地府，意常清静步天宫。 须依贫乐同颜子，莫要悭贪爱邓通。 学取终南师叔马，赤穷穷地堵环中。 赠郑仙 舍俗幽居物外庵，潜心灭迹绝论谈。 妙除浊秽清贫乐，用涤无明淡素甘。 蓬户不扃何所碍，一瓢常饮为忘贪。 安神寂默翛然坐，认透星光日月三。 赠韩家郎君在家修行 崇真起善立玄堂，谨奉朝昏两炷香。 内侍孀亲行孝道，外持真正合三光。 常行矜悯提贫困，每施慈悲挈下殃。 他日聪明如省悟，也应归去到仙乡。 赠门人安然子等 风子微言启众曹，等闲休把气神劳。 欲求海底成多宝，须炼山头绝一毫。 心逐有情伤气火，意游攀爱害神刀。 愿公早悟虚华境，免向人间再一遭。 赠杨姑 投玄八十道姑杨，一朵琼花秋后芳。 玉盏满添清静水，金炉须热慧灵香。 如今已获将来福，从此何疑过去殃。 寂湛虚堂无罜碍，自然宝鼎现霞光。 题孔先生埪中 空门寂寂锁灵泉，喜趣灵泉玄上玄。 僻静每招闲客至，幽居常共马风眠。 清凉境界超尘路，履此方知别有天。 行者肯来低处觅，便教瞥地见神仙。 赠浚州王三校尉 王公吉善爱玄流，劝我勤勤倒玉瓯。 积善迤於心上起，垒功须向性中求。 利他损己通真理，忍辱慈悲达妙幽。 平等顺和常大道，三人同上大神舟。 题云溪庵 云溪高隐卧烟霞，默饮阳晶与月华。 雾敛丹台生瑞草，云收灵腑结琼葩。 青龙吐火烹金茗，白虎跑泉溉玉芽。 龙虎媾交功九转，刀圭一粒捧丹砂。 述怀 自慕贫闲探妙机，便知身入白云飞。 逍遥物外超尘网，脱洒怀中解垢衣。 恐损阴功搜己过，虑伤道德怯人非。 他时九转丹砂就，同约三仙从我归。 又 挫锐摧强作善良，顿然心法两俱忘。 鼎中频起金刚焰，炉内常燃般若香。 玉药乍芳惟独采，蟠桃初熟与先尝。 莫言迢递华胥国，了了空虚路不长。 又 一条捷径入仙源，洞口灵云覆翠巅。 风浪起时挥慧剑，玄波澄处采金莲。 蛟龙降去离宫卧，猛虎擒来坎户眠。 二物定闲人事尽，功圆行满产胎仙。 又 为慕仙源景物长，涤除灵地布琼芳。 南宫赤子居凉殿，北海乌龟住绛房。 清静洞中囚白虎，无为山上牧青羊。 自从鼎内云收后，常饮醍醐卧醉乡。 又 寂寥潇洒道人家，守弱随缘度岁华。 御冷粗衣唯纸布，充饥淡饭有齑菰。 忘言淡薄人情远，绝虑幽闲道况赊。 着恋妻儿名利者，限临猛悟悔如麻。 又 天机深远少人知，一粒刀圭午上持。 雾卷古潭秋静夜，云收碧嶂月明时。 蛟龙捉得囚高鼎，猛虎擒来锁坎池。

**Seven-Lawregulated Verses: Inscribed at Chaoyuan Palace in Luoyang**
The palace gates stand still, sealed in auspicious mist,
Yet ancient traces and sacred marks remain as if present.
Clouds shroud linked branches where the alchemical cauldron boils,
Rosy dawns rise from the numinous well to irrigate the elixir spring.
The sun’s essence refines the land of Huaxu,
The moon’s spirit gathers the realm of endless day.
Since the Purple Edict summoned the Perfected away,
Who now shall succeed as the Great Luo Immortal?

**Visiting Ling Mountain Temple**
Leisurely I wander clouds and waters to seek the Chan grove,
Jade-like bamboo glows thickly against emerald peaks.
The Jade Pillar Peak stands high, unstained by dust,
Ling Mountain Temple hides where few may find its realm.
White snow blends in even drifts like jade spread,
Golden blossoms scatter amidst yellow flowers.
On an autumn night by the limpid ancient pool,
Osmanthus blooms alone reveal the original heart.

**Visiting Magistrate Liu’s Garden**
A host of worthies invites me to admire the fragrant bloom,
After rain clears, I pass alone through the bright gate.
By the balustrade, peonies vie in splendor,
Around the courtyard, butterflies contend in lofty flight.
The wind stirs willow eyes with ruthless intent,
The rain washes flower hearts clean of right and wrong.
All things merge into spring’s single qi,
Selfless, it scatters its fragrance everywhere.

**Presented to the White-Haired Elder Guo of Xinzhong**
How many ever reach the white-haired elder’s state?
Birth, aging, sickness, and death mark the beginning and end.
Foul impurities and rank desires shorten lifespan,
While greed and envy turn the mind to darkness.
Love and hate make transcending the world difficult,
Desireless and passionless, one attains liberation.
Fortunate that paths to heaven and hell exist—
Sages and fools, delusion and awakening, all rest with you.

**Presented to Immortal Cheng of Yunyang**
The greatest fear in cultivation is stubborn bronze,
For one clad in stubborn bronze gains no merit.
When the heart stirs with false dust, one sinks to the underworld,
When the mind abides in purity, one walks the celestial palace.
You must emulate Yanzi’s joy in poverty,
Not crave Deng Tong’s wealth and greed.
Learn from Master Ma of Zhongnan,
Who dwelt in utter destitution within the ring.

**Presented to Immortal Zheng**
Leaving the world, he dwells in a hermitage beyond things,
Silently cultivating, erasing traces, ceasing all debate.
Wondrously he purges filth, delighting in pure poverty,
Using clarity to wash away ignorance, content with plainness.
His thatched door stands unbarred—what hinders him?
A single gourd suffices to quench greed.
Calm and still, he sits in effortless ease,
Piercing through the three lights of sun, moon, and stars.

**Presented to Young Master Han on Cultivating the Dao at Home**
Uphold truth, initiate goodness, establish the mysterious hall,
Diligently offer incense morning and evening.
Within, serve your widowed mother with filial devotion,
Without, uphold integrity to align with the Three Lights.
Always act with compassion to lift the poor and distressed,
Frequently extend mercy to relieve those in misfortune.
If one day your wisdom awakens,
You too shall return to the immortal realm.

**Presented to Disciples Anranzi and Others**
The Master’s subtle words enlighten all,
Do not idly exhaust qi and spirit.
To seek the treasures of the sea’s depths,
Refine the mountain’s summit to eliminate the slightest flaw.
The heart chasing worldly passions harms qi and fire,
The mind wandering in craving injures the spirit’s blade.
I hope you awaken early to the illusory world,
And avoid another cycle in the human realm.

**Presented to the Eighty-Year-Old Daoist Nun Yang**
Seeking the mysterious, the eighty-year-old Daoist nun Yang,
A jade-like flower blooming after autumn’s frost.
Her jade cup brims with water of purity and stillness,
Her golden censer must glow with fragrant wisdom.
Now she has secured future blessings,
Henceforth, what doubt remains of past misfortunes?
In the serene and empty hall, free from obstruction,
The precious cauldron naturally reveals rosy light.

**Inscribed at Master Kong’s Hermitage**
The empty gate stands silent, sealing the numinous spring,
Delighting in the spring’s profound mystery upon mystery.
Secluded, it often draws idle visitors,
In quietude, it shares its abode with the sleeping phoenix.
The cool and pure realm transcends the dusty path—
Only by treading here does one know another heaven exists.
If the seeker is willing to look in lowly places,
They shall suddenly behold the immortal.

**Presented to Marshal Wang of Junzhou**
Noble Wang delights in the mysterious current,
Urging me earnestly to invert the jade cup.
Goodness accumulates gradually from the heart,
Merit must be sought within one’s nature.
Benefiting others while diminishing the self reveals true principle,
Enduring insults with compassion unlocks wondrous depths.
Equanimity and harmony are the great Dao—
Three shall ascend together in the divine vessel.

**Inscribed at Yunxi Hermitage**
At Yunxi, the recluse lies amidst mist and rosy clouds,
Silently drinking the sun’s essence and moon’s radiance.
Mists disperse from the cinnabar terrace, revealing auspicious herbs,
Clouds gather around the numinous crucible, forming jade-like blooms.
The Azure Dragon exhales fire to brew golden tea,
The White Tiger digs springs to irrigate jade sprouts.
When dragon and tiger unite, the work completes nine cycles,
A single grain of the elixir holds cinnabar’s treasure.

**Expressing My Aspirations**
I admire poverty and leisure to explore the wondrous mechanism,
Thus knowing my body enters the realm of white clouds.
Carefree beyond the world, I transcend the dust’s net,
Unfettered within, I shed the garment of defilement.
Fearing harm to hidden merit, I examine my faults,
Anxious to avoid moral injury, I shun others’ blame.
When the nine-cycled cinnabar elixir is complete,
I shall invite the Three Immortals to return with me.

**Again**
Blunting sharpness, subduing strength, I become good,
Suddenly both heart and method are forgotten.
In the cauldron, the vajra flame frequently rises,
In the furnace, the prajna incense perpetually burns.
The jade elixir first blooms—only I gather it,
The immortal peach ripens—I taste it first.
Do not say the land of Huaxu is distant,
In perfect emptiness, the path is not long.

**Again**
A single shortcut leads to the immortal source,
At the cave’s mouth, numinous clouds veil the verdant peak.
When winds and waves arise, wield the sword of wisdom,
Where the mysterious waves settle, pluck the golden lotus.
The dragon subdued, it sleeps in the Li palace,
The tiger captured, it rests in the Kan chamber.
When these two are pacified, worldly affairs end,
With merit complete and conduct fulfilled, the embryonic immortal is born.

**Again**
Longing for the immortal source’s enduring scenes,

In the Pure and Still Grotto, the White Tiger is imprisoned,
On the Effortless Mountain, the Azure Sheep are herded.
Since the clouds gathered within the cauldron,
I perpetually drink the divine nectar, lying in drunken bliss.

The Daoist’s home is desolate and free,
Embracing weakness, following conditions, passing the years.
Against the cold, coarse robes of paper suffice,
To sate hunger, plain rice with greens will do.
Forgetting words, distant from worldly ties,
Abandoning thoughts, the Dao’s profundity grows.
Those attached to wives, children, fame, and profit—
When their limits approach, their regrets shall be as thick as hemp.

Mists roll back from the ancient pool on an autumn night,
Clouds gather from the green peaks in the moon’s glow.
The dragon is seized and imprisoned in the lofty cauldron,
The tiger is captured and bound in the Kan pool.
